Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Chemistry of Nanoscale Architectures for Imaging and Environmental Applications at Jackson State University Serving Minority and Disadvantaged Students
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemistry Division is funding Professor Paresh Ray and colleagues at Jackson State University (JSU), to host an REU site called "Chemistry of Nanoscale Architectures for Imaging and Environmental Applications at Jackson State University Serving Minority and Disadvantaged Students." This REU site will provide ten weeks of research and educational experiences for eight undergraduate students from traditionally underrepresented minorities and non-research intensive universities. Built around a theme of understanding the imaging and environmental applications of nanoscale architectures and their environmental implications, this REU site is led by an interdisciplinary team of chemists, nanotechnologists, environmental engineers, and environmental scientists. The REU students will be provided with career and educational activities that include nanoscience-related research projects, short courses on nanoscience and workshops on scientific writing. There will also be training in presentation skills and counseling on graduate study in chemistry.

This REU Site, hosted at the fifth largest HBCU (Historically Black College and University) in the nation, seeks to promote diversity in the future scientific workforce in nanoscience. Through their experience at JSU, the participants will be provided with valuable educational/research experiences as they consider career pathways in science. For the students from non-research intensive institutions, this will be an experience that they might otherwise not have. The principal broader impact of this REU site is on the training and mentoring of African American and disadvantaged students with great potential for careers in STEM.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major objectives of this REU proposal are: 1) to expose students to the collaborative environmental nanoscience projects by bringing together a group of interdisciplinary faculty members at JSU from different disciplines; 2) to provide opportunities for JSU-REU participants to excel in research on environmental nanoscience and promote the acquisition of skills necessary for scientific discovery; 3) to create an REU educational/research atmosphere that includes journal clubs, weekly seminars, workshops on scientific writing, presentation and research ethics, research skill development and strategies to compete for national  and international graduate fellowship. To achieve the above goals and objectives, during the funding period, the JSU REU Site recruited total 24 undergraduate students for the 2016, 2017 and 2018 summer program. Among the participants more than 75% were African Americans and more than 90% were females.  These numbers reflect our program’s emphasis on training underrepresented minorities.. During funding period, we have published 4 papers in good quality journals with 100% of these publications involving  REU students. The broader impact of this funding period lies in development of an REU research environment for JSU, a historically black university, to conduct cutting-edge materials research and education programs that involve undergraduate African American students and women. Faculty members at JSU have been able to participate in the materials related research and work with REU students who are participated in the advance materials research areas. During funding period, all REU participants have joined in our educational, and outreach activities in science museum, children museum, different public schools and local library. Through innovative programs and lecture courses, our REU program  allows the development of JSU as a center of excellence in advanced nanomaterial and polymer material research . Undergraduate students from underrepresented groups and others have exposure to JSU faculty through lectures, research visits, and use of the state-of-the-art facilities at JSU core facilities. Finally, the REU program played an important role in the larger framework of the JSU’s research enterprise by promoting inter-departmental collaborations among faculty members.
